Comments_List: I learned how to do many critical quantum chemistry derivations and how to apply their results.
How to think about quantum chemistry classically. A great introduction to a wide range of topics including perturbation theory, Fourier transforms, rabi cycling, and how to solve a two level system.
Very well taught, notes well organised
Studied a lot of very useful knowledge of Quantum.
This course gave a good introduction to quantum mechanics and provided the tools needed to tackle larger problems. In particular, the computational assignments were informative and useful.
A firm base level understanding of Quantum Mechanics. The mathematic foundation given by this class is invaluable.

The notes are a bit too sparse. I appreciate that they try to cut back on the reading, but I think the brevity does not convey the information with the same conceptual framework. Also sometimes the mathematics is not fully explained which is challenging.

It could be improved by asking students to rework the notes so they are more helpful for future students.
I liked how the class topics were largely directed by what the students were interested in.
It could be improved with more overviews of topics covered, and more problem sets to get a better idea of the subject.

Overall, the course was very interesting and useful. It was helpful that course notes were provided online. The computational assignments were interesting and useful. One suggestion for improvement is to provide more/longer exams. In comparison to Molrad which had 4 two-hour exams, this course had only 2 one-hour exams and a final which meant that each question was worth much more to the final grade.

The course went at a great pace. Often long derivations cause people to get lost but there was always a feeling that students could stop and ask to go back if they got lost. 

The course book was very helpful in the beginning but could use a little expansion after the first month's material to match with the detail given in lecture.Greater feedback on the exercises would be useful after turning them in.

Maybe. I think there is a real benefit to understanding derivations. I would recommend the course insofar as the student understood the class is about deriving quantum chemistry from first principles. The crux of the class is learning those derivations on your own.

I would recommend this course to a student who wants to learn about quantum mechanics. This course was especially useful when taken with Molecules and Radiation, as much of the syllabus was complementary.
Yes. The mathematic basis received is very important.
